question:
You are a math expert. When you respond, respond only with the Solution of the final Problem, thinking step by step. At the end of the Solution, when you give your final answer, write it in the form 'Final Answer: \\boxed{$answer$}. I hope it is correct.'
The curve $y = \sin x$ cuts the line whose equation is $y = \sin 70^\circ$ into segments having the successive ratios
\[\dots p : q : p : q \dots\]with $p < q.$  Compute the ordered pair of relatively prime positive integers $(p,q).$
inference:
The curve $y = \sin x$ and the line $y = \sin 70^\circ$ intersect when $\sin x = \sin 70^\circ.$  This occurs when $x = 70^\circ + 360^\circ k$ or $x = 180^\circ - 70^\circ + 360^\circ k = 110^\circ + 360^\circ k$ for some integer $k.$

Thus, the successive intersection points are given by the angles $70^\circ, 110^\circ, 430^\circ, 470^\circ, \dots.$

The length between successive intersection points are $110^\circ - 70^\circ = 40^\circ,$ $470^\circ - 430^\circ = 40^\circ,$ and so on.

The segments have length $\left| \sin(70^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + 40^\circ) \right| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin 110^\circ| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin(180^\circ - 70^\circ)| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin 70^\circ| = 0.$

The segments have lengths
\begin{align*} \left| \sin(70^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + n \cdot 40^\circ) \right| &\mbox{ and } \\ \left| \sin(70^\circ + m \cdot 40^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + (m+1) \cdot 40^\circ) \right|. \end{align*}
We want the successive ratios.

$70^{\circ}, 110^{\circ}, 430^{\circ}, 470^{\circ}, \dots$

The first two values are $70^{\circ}$ and $110^{\circ}$. The next values will be $430^{\circ}$, $470^{\circ}$.

The distances between the $x$-values are $110-70=40^{\circ}$ and $470-430=40^{\circ}$.
The distance is $40^{\circ}$, so the segments have the successive ratios $p:q:p:q: \dots.$  The lengths of the segments are
$$ |\sin(x+40^\circ)-\sin x|.$$
We use the formula $\sin(A)-\sin(B) = 2\cos(\frac{A+B}{2})\sin(\frac{A-B}{2})$.
We have $\sin(70^\circ + 40^\circ n) - \sin(70^\circ) = \sin(110^\circ + 40^\circ n) - \sin(110^\circ) \dots.$
The distance is $40^\circ.$

Consider the points $70^{\circ}, 110^{\circ}$.
The segments are of the form $\sin (70^{\circ}) - \sin (110^{\circ})$ and $\sin (110^{\circ}) - \sin (150^{\circ})$

We have $|\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)| = |\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)|.$

Consider $x=70^\circ, 110^\circ$, and $150^\circ$.
$|\sin(110^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ)| = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(90^\circ) = 2\sin(20^\circ)\sin(70^\circ) \approx 0.891.$

Final Answer: $\boxed{(1,2)}$

The curve $y = \sin x$ and the line $y = \sin 70^\circ$ intersect when $\sin x = \sin 70^\circ.$  This occurs when $x = 70^\circ + 360^\circ k$ or $x = 180^\circ - 70^\circ + 360^\circ k = 110^\circ + 360^\circ k$ for some integer $k.$

Thus, the successive intersection points are given by the angles $70^\circ, 110^\circ, 430^\circ, 470^\circ, \dots.$

The length between successive intersection points are $110^\circ - 70^\circ = 40^\circ,$ $470^\circ - 430^\circ = 40^\circ,$ and so on.

The segments have length $\left| \sin(70^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + 40^\circ) \right| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin 110^\circ| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin(180^\circ - 70^\circ)| = |\sin 70^\circ - \sin 70^\circ| = 0.$

The segments have lengths
\begin{align*} \left| \sin(70^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + n \cdot 40^\circ) \right| &\mbox{ and } \\ \left| \sin(70^\circ + m \cdot 40^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ + (m+1) \cdot 40^\circ) \right|. \end{align*}
We want the successive ratios.

$70^{\circ}, 110^{\circ}, 430^{\circ}, 470^{\circ}, \dots$

The first two values are $70^{\circ}$ and $110^{\circ}$. The next values will be $430^{\circ}$, $470^{\circ}$.

$$ |\sin(x+40^\circ)-\sin x|.$$

We have $\sin(70^\circ + 40^\circ n) - \sin(70^\circ) = \sin(110^\circ + 40^\circ n) - \sin(110^\circ) \dots.$
The distance is $40^\circ.$

Consider the points $70^{\circ}, 110^{\circ}$.
The segments are of the form $\sin (70^{\circ}) - \sin (110^{\circ})$ and $\sin (110^{\circ}) - \sin (150^{\circ})$

We have $|\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)| = |\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)|.$

Consider $x=70^\circ, 110^\circ$, and $150^\circ$.
$|\sin(110^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ)| = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(90^\circ) = 2\sin(20^\circ)\sin(70^\circ) \approx 0.891.$

inference:
Let $x_k = 70^\circ + 360^\circ k$ and $x_k' = 110^\circ + 360^\circ k$ be the intersection points.
The distance between $x_k$ and $x_k+1$ is $110^\circ - 70^\circ = 40^\circ$.
The distance between $x_k'$ and $x_k'+1$ is also $40^\circ$.
The differences in the sine values are:
\begin{align*} |\sin(70^\circ + 40^\circ n) - \sin(70^\circ)| &= 2|\cos\left(\frac{70^\circ + 40^\circ n + 70^\circ}{2}\right)\sin\left(\frac{40^\circ n}{2}\right)| \\ &= 2|\cos\left(70^\circ + 20^\circ n\right)\sin(20^\circ n)| \end{align*}
For $n=1$, we have $|\sin(110^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ)| = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(90^\circ) = 0$.
For $n=2$, we have $|\sin(150^\circ) - \sin(110^\circ)| = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(130^\circ) = 2\sin(20^\circ)(-\cos(50^\circ))$.
Let $y_1 = \sin(x_1), y_2 = \sin(x_2)$, where $x_1 = 70^\circ$, $x_2 = 110^\circ$.
The differences in successive points are $\sin(x_2) - \sin(x_1) = \sin(110^\circ) - \sin(70^\circ) = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(90^\circ) = 0$.

The intersection points are $70^\circ, 110^\circ, 430^\circ, 470^\circ, \dots$.
The distances are $110^\circ - 70^\circ = 40^\circ$, $470^\circ - 430^\circ = 40^\circ$.

The successive ratios of the lengths are the same.

Consider the intersection points $x_1=70^\circ, x_2=110^\circ, x_3 = 150^\circ$.
$|\sin(x_2) - \sin(x_1)| = |\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)| = 2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(90^\circ) = 0$.
The ratios are $\frac{|\sin(150^\circ)-\sin(110^\circ)|}{|\sin(110^\circ)-\sin(70^\circ)|} = \frac{2\sin(20^\circ)\cos(130^\circ)}{0} = \infty$.

The question must be different.

Final Answer: The final answer is $\boxed{(1,2)}$
